00002 
00003 #  Fun.pm
00004 # methods:
00005 #   new Fun($rule,$graphRef)
00006 #       If $rule is a subroutine then a function object is created, 
00007 #        with default data. If the graphRef is present the function is
00008 #       installed into the
00009 #       graph and the domain is reset to the graphRef's domain.         
00010 #       If the $rule is another function object then a copy of that function is 
00011 #       made with all of its data  and it is installed in the graphRef if that is present.
00012 #       In this case the domain of the function is not affected by the domain of the graphRef.
00013 #   initial data
00014 #       @domain = ($tstart, $tstop)   the domain of the function        -- initially (-1,1)
00015 #       steps                         the number of steps in drawing    -- initially 20
00016 #       color                         the pen color to draw with        -- initially 'red'
00017 #       weight                        the width of the pen in pixels    --  initially 2
00018 #       rule                          reference to a subroutine
00019 #                                       which calculates the function   -- initially null
00020 #       graph                         reference to the enclosing graph  -- initially $ref or else null
00021 
00022 # What will the domain of new Fun($rule, $graphRef) be?
00023 #           It will be the same as $rule if $rule is actually another function object
00024 #                   ELSE        the same as the domain of $graphRef if that is present
00025 #                   ELSE        the interval (-1,1)
00026 #   public access methods:    
00027 #       domain
00028 #       steps
00029 #       color
00030 #       rule
00031 #       weight
00032 ;
00033 
00034 =head1 NAME
00035 
00036     Fun
00037 
00038 =head1 SYNPOSIS
00039 
00040     use Carp;
00041     use GD;
00042     use WWPlot;
00043     use Fun;
00044     $fn = new Fun( rule_reference);
00045     $fn = new Fun( rule_reference , graph_reference);
00046     $fn = new Fun ( x_rule_ref, y_rule_ref );
00047     $fn = new Fun ( x_rule_ref, y_rule_ref, graph_ref );
00048 
00049 =head1 DESCRIPTION
00050 
00051 This module defines a parametric or non-parametric function object.  The function object is designed to
00052 be inserted into a graph object defined by WWPlot.  
00053 
00054 The following functions are provided:
00055 
00056 
00057 
00058 =head2  new  (non-parametric version)
00059 
00060 =over 4 
00061 
00062 =item   $fn = new Fun( rule_reference);
00063 
00064 rule_reference is a reference to a subroutine which accepts a numerical value and returns a numerical value.
00065 The Fun object will draw the graph associated with this subroutine.  
00066 For example: $rule = sub { my $x= shift; $x**2};  will produce a plot of the x squared.
00067 The new method returns a reference to the function object.
00068 
00069 =item   $fn = new Fun( rule_reference , graph_reference);
00070 
00071 The function is also placed into the printing queue of the graph object pointed to by graph_reference and the 
00072 domain of the function object is set to the domain of the graph.
00073 
00074 =back
00075 
00076 =head2  new  (parametric version)   
00077 
00078 =over 4 
00079 
00080 =item   $fn = new Fun ( x_rule_ref, y_rule_ref );
00081 
00082 A parametric function object is created where the subroutines refered to by x_rule_ref and y_rule_ref define
00083 the x and y outputs in terms of the input t.  
00084 
00085 =item   $fn = new Fun ( x_rule_ref, y_rule_ref, graph_ref );
00086 
00087 This variant inserts the parametric function object into the graph object referred to by graph_ref.  The domain
00088 of the function object is not adjusted.  The domain's default value is (-1, 1).
00089 
00090 =back
00091 
00092 =head2 Properites
00093 
00094     All of the properties are set using the construction $new_value = $fn->property($new_value) 
00095     and read using $current_value = $fn->property()
00096 
00097 =over 4 
00098 
00099 =item tstart, tstop, steps
00100 
00101 The domain of the function is (tstart, tstop).  steps is the number of subintervals
00102 used in graphing the function.
00103 
00104 =item color
00105 
00106 The color used to draw the function is specified by a word such as 'orange' or 'yellow'. 
00107 C<$fn->color('blue')> sets the drawing color to blue.  The RGB values for the color are defined in the graph
00108 object in which the function is drawn.  If the color, e.g. 'mauve', is not defined by the graph object
00109 then the function is drawn using the color 'default_color' which is always defined (and usually black).
00110 
00111 =item x_rule
00112 
00113 A reference to the subroutine used to calculate the x value of the graph.  This is set to the identity function (x = t )
00114 when using the function object in non-parametric mode.
00115 
00116 =item y_rule
00117 
00118 A reference to the subroutine used to calculate the y value of the graph.
00119 
00120 =item weight
00121 
00122 The width in pixels of the pen used to draw the graph. The pen is square.
00123 
00124 =back
00125 
00126 =head2 Actions which affect more than one property.
00127 
00128 =over 4
00129 
00130 =item rule 
00131 
00132 This defines a non-parametric function. 
00133 
00134     $fn->rule(sub {my $x =shift; $x**2;} ) 
00135     
00136     is equivalent to
00137     
00138     $fn->x_rule(sub {my $x = shift; $x;});
00139     $fn->y_rule(sub {my $x = shift; $x**2;);
00140     
00141     $fn->rule() returns the reference to the y_rule.
00142 
00143 =item domain
00144 
00145 $array_ref = $fn->domain(-1,1) sets tstart to -1 and tstop to 1 and 
00146 returns a reference to an array containing this pair of numbers.
00147 
00148 
00149 =item draw
00150 
00151 $fn->draw($graph_ref) draws the function in the graph object pointed to by $graph_ref. If one of
00152 the points bounding a subinterval is undefined then that segment is not drawn.  This usually does the "right thing" for
00153 functions which have simple singularities.
00154 
00155 The graph object must
00156 respond to the methods below.  The draw call is mainly for internal use by the graph object. Most users will not
00157 call it directly.
00158 
00159 =over 4 
00160 
00161 =item   $graph_ref->{colors} 
00162 
00163 a hash containing the defined colors
00164 
00165 =item $graph_ref ->im       
00166 
00167 a GD image object
00168 
00169 =item $graph_ref->lineTo(x,y, color_number)
00170 
00171 draw line to the point (x,y) from the current position using the specified color.  To obtain the color number
00172 use a construction such as C<$color_number = $graph_ref->{colors}{'blue'};>
00173 
00174 =item $graph_ref->lineTo(x,y,gdBrushed)
00175 
00176 draw line to the point (x,y) using the pattern set by SetBrushed (see GD documentation)
00177 
00178 =item $graph_ref->moveTo(x,y)
00179 
00180 set the current position to (x,y)
00181 
00182 =back    
00183 
00184 =back
00185 
00186 =cut
00187 
00188 BEGIN {
00189     be_strict(); # an alias for use strict.  This means that all global variable must contain main:: as a prefix.
00190 }

00192 package Fun;
00193 
00194 #use "WWPlot.pm";
00195 #Because of the way problem modules are loaded 'use' is disabled.
00196 
00197 @Fun::ISA = qw(WWPlot);
00198 # import gdBrushed from GD.  It unclear why, but a good many global methods haven't been imported.
00199 sub gdBrushed {
00200     &GD::gdBrushed();
00201 }
00202 
00203 my $GRAPH_REFERENCE = "WWPlot";   
00204 my $FUNCTION_REFERENCE = "Fun";
00205 
00206 my %fields =(
00207         tstart      =>  -1,  # (tstart,$tstop) constitutes the domain
00208         tstop       =>  1,
00209         steps       =>  50,
00210         color       =>  'blue',
00211         x_rule      => \&identity,
00212         y_rule      => \&identity,
00213         weight      =>  2,  # line thickness
00214 );
00215 
00216 
00217 sub new {
00218     my $class               =   shift;
00219 #   my ($rule,$graphRef)    =   @_;
00220 
00221     my $self            = { 
00222 #               _permitted  =>  \%fields,
00223                 %fields,
00224     };
00225     
00226     bless $self, $class;
00227     $self -> _initialize(@_);
00228     return $self;
00229 }
00230 
00231 sub identity {  # the identity function
00232     shift;
00233 }
00234 sub rule  { # non-parametric functions are defined using rule; use x_rule and y_rule to define parametric functions
00235     my $self = shift;
00236     my $rule = shift;
00237     my $out;
00238     if ( defined($rule)  ){
00239         $self->x_rule (\&identity);
00240         $self->y_rule($rule);
00241         $out = $self->y_rule;
00242     } else {
00243         $out = $self->y_rule
00244     }
00245     $out;
00246 }
00247 
00248 sub _initialize {     
00249     my  $self   =   shift;
00250     my  ($xrule,$yrule, $rule,$graphRef);
00251     my @input = @_;
00252     if (ref($input[$#input]) eq $GRAPH_REFERENCE ) {
00253         $graphRef = pop @input;  # get the last argument if it refers to a graph.  
00254         $graphRef->fn($self);     # Install this function in the graph.
00255     } 
00256   
00257     if ( @input == 1 ) {                 # only one argument left -- this is a non parametric function
00258         $rule = $input[0];
00259         if ( ref($rule) eq $FUNCTION_REFERENCE ) {  # clone another function
00260             my $k;
00261             foreach $k (keys %fields) {
00262                 $self->{$k} = $rule->{$k};
00263             }
00264         } else {
00265             $self->rule($rule);                     
00266             if (ref($graphRef) eq $GRAPH_REFERENCE) { # use graph to initialize domain
00267                 $self->domain($graphRef->xmin,$graphRef->xmax);
00268             }
00269         }
00270     } elsif (@input == 2 ) {   #  two arguments -- parametric functions
00271             $self->x_rule($input[0]);
00272             $self->y_rule($input[1]);
00273         
00274     } else {
00275         die "Fun.pm:_initialize: Can't call function with more than two arguments";
00276     }
00277     
00278 }
00279 
00280 sub draw {
00281     my $self = shift;  # this function 
00282     my $g = shift;   # the graph containing the function.
00283     my $color;   # get color scheme from graph
00284     if ( defined( $g->{'colors'}{$self->color} )  ) {
00285         $color = $g->{'colors'}{$self->color}; 
00286     } else {
00287         $color = $g->{'colors'}{'default_color'};  # what you do if the color isn't there
00288     }
00289     my $brush = new GD::Image($self->weight,$self->weight);
00290     my $brush_color = $brush->colorAllocate($g->im->rgb($color));  # transfer color
00291     $g->im->setBrush($brush);
00292     my $stepsize = ( $self->tstop - $self->tstart )/$self->steps;
00293     
00294     my ($t,$x,$i,$y);
00295     my $x_prev = undef;
00296     my $y_prev = undef; 
00297     foreach $i (0..$self->steps) {
00298             $t=$stepsize*$i + $self->tstart;
00299             $x=&{$self->x_rule}( $t );;
00300             $y=&{$self->y_rule}( $t );
00301 # Points where the function were not defined were not being handled
00302 # gracefully.  They would come as blank y values, which would ultimately
00303 # trigger errors downstream unless y was undefined.
00304         if(defined($y) and $y eq "") { $y = undef; }
00305             if (defined($x) && defined($x_prev) && defined($y) && defined($y_prev) ) {
00306                 $g->lineTo($x, $y, gdBrushed);
00307             } else {
00308                 $g->moveTo($x, $y) if defined($x) && defined($y);
00309             }
00310             $x_prev = $x;
00311             $y_prev = $y;
00312         }
00313 }
00314 
00315 sub domain {
00316     my $self =shift;
00317     my $tstart = shift;
00318     my $tstop  = shift;
00319     if (defined($tstart) && defined($tstop) ) {
00320         $self->tstart($tstart);
00321         $self->tstop($tstop);
00322     }
00323         [$self->tstart,$self->tstop];   
00324 }

00329 sub tstart {
00330     my $self = shift;
00331     my $type = ref($self) || die "$self is not an object";
00332     unless (exists $self->{tstart} ) {
00333         die "Can't find tstart field in object of class $type";
00334     }
00335     
00336     if (@_) {
00337         return $self->{tstart} = shift;
00338     } else {
00339         return $self->{tstart}
00340     }
00341 }
